concepts.title: Air Has Weight and Exerts Pressure
concepts.content: Air has weight â€” as proved by the textbook experiment where a fully inflated balloon tips the balance lower than a deflated balloon. Anything with weight exerts pressure on what lies below it. The entire column of atmosphere above us exerts pressure on Earth's surface â€” this is called air pressure (atmospheric pressure). Air pressure creates various weather phenomena like storms and precipitation. The unit for measuring air pressure is millibar (mb) or hectopascal (hPa).

examples.text: Blown-up balloon heavier than deflated balloon â€” proves air has weight
Climbers on Everest breathe through oxygen masks â€” air pressure so low, not enough oxygen
Aircraft cabins are pressurised â€” outside air pressure at 10,000m is too low to breathe

keyPoints: Air has weight â€” proved by balloon experiment (inflated balloon heavier)
Weight of air above us = air pressure on Earth's surface
Air pressure creates weather phenomena: storms, precipitation, etc.
Sea level air pressure â‰ˆ 1013 mb (standard atmosphere)
Air pressure measured using a barometer
concepts.funFact: âš–ï¸ The entire atmosphere pressing down on your body amounts to about 10,000 kg force â€” equivalent to 10 tonnes pressing on you! You don't feel it because your body pushes back with equal force from inside. But at high altitude, this pressure is much less â€” making it hard to breathe.

concepts.title: Factors Affecting Air Pressure â€” Altitude and Temperature
concepts.content: Two main factors affect air pressure: (1) Altitude: As altitude increases, the air column above becomes shorter and lighter, so air pressure decreases. Air also becomes thinner (less dense) at high altitudes. (2) Temperature: Hot air expands, becomes lighter, and rises â€” leaving less air near the surface, so pressure decreases. Cold air is heavier, sinks, and creates higher pressure. The flying lantern experiment demonstrates this: hot air inside the lantern rises, lifting it up.

Pressure at top of Mt Everest (~8849m): only ~300 mb â€” about â…“ of sea level pressure
Hot desert regions: very low pressure (high temperature â†’ hot air rises)

keyPoints: Higher altitude â†’ lower air pressure (less air column above)
Higher temperature â†’ lower air pressure (hot air expands, rises, less air at surface)
Lower temperature â†’ higher air pressure (cold air sinks, more air at surface)
Flying lantern rises because hot air inside is lighter = low pressure

concepts.title: Pressure Belts of the World
concepts.content: Due to uneven heating and cooling across latitudes, the earth has distinct pressure belts: (1) Equatorial Low Pressure Belt (0Â°â€“5Â° N/S): Hot equatorial air rises â†’ low pressure. Also called Doldrums â€” calm, no regular winds. (2) Sub-tropical High Pressure Belt (25Â°â€“35Â° N/S): Descending dry air â†’ high pressure. Also called Horse Latitudes. (3) Sub-polar Low Pressure Belt (55Â°â€“65Â° N/S): Polar and tropical air meet â†’ rise â†’ low pressure. (4) Polar High Pressure Belt (80Â°â€“90Â° N/S): Very cold air â†’ sinks â†’ high pressure.

examples.text: Equatorial belt (near 0Â°): extremely hot all year â†’ air always rising â†’ always low pressure
Subtropical high pressure (25Â°-35Â°): hot, dry descending air â†’ world's major deserts here (Sahara, Thar)
Polar high pressure (near poles): extremely cold â†’ dense, sinking air â†’ high pressure

keyPoints: Equatorial low pressure belt (0Â°â€“5Â°): hot air rises â†’ low pressure â†’ called Doldrums
Subtropical high pressure belt (25Â°â€“35Â°): descending dry air â†’ high pressure â†’ called Horse Latitudes
Sub-polar low pressure belt (55Â°â€“65Â°): warm and cold air meet â†’ rise â†’ low pressure
Polar high pressure belt (80Â°â€“90Â°): cold dense air sinks â†’ high pressure
World's major deserts lie in the subtropical high pressure belts

With no wind to sail and limited water, horses being transported to the Americas were sometimes thrown overboard to save water. That's how a belt of calm air got named after horses!

concepts.title: Doldrums and Horse Latitudes
concepts.content: The Equatorial Low Pressure belt is also called the Doldrums â€” a region near the equator (0Â°â€“5Â° N/S) where winds are usually calm or variable. The intense heat causes air to rise, leaving a surface zone of calm. Old sailing ships often got stranded here for weeks. The Subtropical High Pressure Belt (25Â°â€“35Â° N/S) is also called Horse Latitudes â€” another calm zone where ships could be becalmed. The sub-tropical high pressure belt is home to the world's great deserts.

examples.text: Sailing ships in Doldrums: no wind â†’ stranded for days/weeks near equator
Sahara, Arabian, Thar, Atacama deserts: all lie in the subtropical high pressure belt
Mumbai, Goa lie near the northern edge of the equatorial belt â€” explains monsoon pattern

keyPoints: Doldrums: equatorial calm zone (0Â°â€“5Â°) â€” rising hot air, no surface winds
Horse Latitudes: subtropical calm zone (25Â°â€“35Â°) â€” descending dry air, calm
Both zones are known for calm or unpredictable winds
World's major deserts lie within the subtropical high pressure belt
India's Thar Desert lies in the subtropical high pressure zone

concepts.title: Relationship Between Temperature Zones and Pressure Belts
concepts.content: Temperature zones (Torrid, Temperate, Frigid) and pressure belts are related but not identical. Temperature zones cover much larger latitudinal ranges than pressure belts. For example, the Temperate zone extends from 23Â°30' to 66Â°30' â€” but each pressure belt is only about 10Â° wide. This is because pressure is influenced not just by latitude but also by local factors like land vs sea distribution, ocean currents, and altitude.

examples.text: Torrid Zone (0Â°â€“23.5Â°): includes both equatorial LOW and subtropical HIGH pressure belts
Temperate Zone (23.5Â°â€“66.5Â°): includes subtropical HIGH, sub-polar LOW belts
Frigid Zone (66.5Â°â€“90Â°): includes polar HIGH pressure belt

keyPoints: Temperature zones and pressure belts are related but not identical in extent
Temperature zones are wider (e.g., Temperate zone spans 43Â°); pressure belts narrower (~10Â° each)
Pressure is influenced by temperature, altitude, land-sea distribution, and ocean currents
India spans multiple pressure zones â€” from equatorial low to subtropical high
Understanding pressure belts is essential for predicting winds (taught in Chapter 5)

test.question: A blown-up balloon is heavier than a deflated balloon. This proves _____.
options: Air pressure increases inside a balloon
test.explanation: The science textbook activity (Class 7) shows that the inflated balloon tips the balance scale â€” proving air has weight. Since it has weight, it exerts pressure on what is below it.

test.question: A flying lantern rises because _____.
options: The candle heats the air inside â€” hot air expands, becomes lighter, and rises along with the lantern
The lantern is made of very light material
Cold air pushes the lantern up
test.explanation: Hot air is lighter (less dense) than cold air. When the candle heats the air inside the lantern, the air expands and becomes lighter. This lighter, low-pressure air rises â€” taking the lantern with it. The same principle explains why equatorial air rises (creating low pressure).

test.question: As you go higher up a mountain, air pressure _____.
options: Decreases â€” less air column above means less weight pressing down
Increases â€” you are closer to the clouds
test.explanation: Air pressure decreases with increasing altitude because there is less air above you (shorter air column = less weight). Air also becomes thinner and less dense at higher altitudes.

test.question: The equatorial region experiences low air pressure because _____.
options: High temperatures cause air to heat up, expand, become lighter, and rise â€” leaving low pressure at surface
There is no air near the equator
Equatorial winds blow all the air away
test.explanation: The equatorial region is the hottest part of Earth â€” intense solar radiation heats the air, making it expand and rise. As air rises, there is less air left at the surface â€” creating a low pressure zone (equatorial low).

test.question: The equatorial low pressure belt is also called _____.
test.explanation: The equatorial calm zone (0Â°â€“5Â° N/S) is called Doldrums â€” where hot rising air creates a near-windless zone at the surface. Old sailing ships often got stuck here.

test.question: World's major hot deserts (Sahara, Thar, Atacama) are mostly located in the _____.
test.explanation: The subtropical high pressure belt (25Â°â€“35Â° N/S) is characterized by descending dry air. This dry, sinking air absorbs moisture rather than releasing it as rain â€” creating the world's major hot deserts: Sahara, Arabian, Thar, Atacama, Kalahari, etc.

test.question: If cold air sinks and warm air rises, what happens to air pressure when temperature decreases?
options: Air pressure increases â€” cold air sinks, adding more air weight at the surface
Air pressure decreases â€” cold air sinks away from the surface
Air pressure stays the same â€” temperature doesn't affect pressure
Air pressure first increases then decreases
test.explanation: When temperature decreases, air becomes cold, dense, and heavy â€” it sinks toward Earth's surface. More air accumulating at the surface means more weight pressing down, resulting in higher air pressure. This is why cold polar regions have high pressure.

test.question: Why are pressure belts narrower than temperature zones?
options: Air pressure is influenced by additional factors beyond just latitude â€” altitude, ocean currents, land-sea distribution
Pressure belts don't exist at all latitudes
Pressure belts shift with seasons more dramatically
test.explanation: Temperature zones are defined only by latitude (angle of sunlight). But air pressure is also affected by altitude, whether it's land or ocean, ocean currents, etc. These additional factors create narrower, more localised pressure patterns than the broad temperature zones.

keyConcepts: Air has weight â†’ exerts air pressure on Earth's surface
Air pressure decreases with increasing altitude (less air column above)
Hot air â†’ low pressure (air rises); Cold air â†’ high pressure (air sinks)

Equatorial Low Pressure Belt (Doldrums): 0Â°â€“5Â°, hot rising air
Subtropical High Pressure Belt (Horse Latitudes): 25Â°â€“35Â°, dry descending air

Hot air has higher pressure â€” FALSE, hot air expands, rises, and creates LOW pressure
Pressure belts and temperature zones cover the same latitudes â€” FALSE, pressure belts are narrower
Doldrums means no weather â€” FALSE, Doldrums has frequent thunderstorms because hot air rises rapidly

Aircraft cabins are pressurised to simulate low altitude â€” passengers don't feel mountain-high pressure
Thar Desert lies in the subtropical high pressure belt â€” that's why it's a desert
Chip packets puff up at high altitude â€” lower outside pressure allows inside air to expand
